questions.text: The sodium iodide symporter is present in all of the following except
questions.explanation:
Location

Function

Thyroid Gland (Option A ruled out)

Active iodide transport for thyroid hormone synthesis (T3, T4) in thyroid follicular cells.

Salivary Glands (Option C ruled out)

Possible role in regulating iodide content in saliva (exact function unclear).

Gastric Mucosa

Potential involvement in iodide transport within the stomach.

Placenta (Option B ruled out)

Allows iodide transfer from maternal to fetal circulation, necessary for the development of the fetal thyroid gland.

Mammary Glands

Facilitates iodide transfer during lactation for breastfeeding purposes.

Kidney

Aids in iodide homeostasis, with expression in renal tubular cells.

Other Tissues

Observed in extrathyroidal tissues with unclear or under-researched roles.

questions.text: What are the chloride equilibrium potentials when the extracellular concentration is 100 mmol/L, and the intracellular concentration is 10 mmol/L?
An individual is in an environment of a temperature of 47ºC. What is the mechanism of heat loss?
Which electrolyte abnormality will lead to cardiac arrhythmia in patients with severe vomiting?

A child with loose stools for one day presented to your OPD. On examination, signs of dehydration were present and the child was given ORS. It facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors?
questions.explanation:
Glucose Transporter

Location

Function

GLUT 1

Various tissues, including brain, erythrocytes, and placenta

Basal glucose uptake in various tissues (constitutive glucose transporter)

GLUT 2

Liver, pancreatic beta cells, renal tubules, small intestine

Facilitates bidirectional glucose transport in liver, pancreatic beta cells, renal tubules, and small intestine

GLUT 3

Brain, placenta, testes

Facilitates high-affinity glucose uptake in neurons and other glucose dependent cells

GLUT 4 (Option C ruled out)

Adipose tissue, skeletal muscle

Insulin-regulated glucose transporter. Facilitates glucose uptake in response to insulin

GLUT 5

Small intestine, testes, kidney, adipose tissue, skeletal muscle

Facilitates fructose transport (also transports glucose to a lesser extent)

SGLT 1

Small intestine, kidney

Sodium-dependent glucose cotransporter. Facilitates active glucose absorption in the small intestine

SGLT 2 (Option B ruled out)

Kidney

Sodium-dependent glucose cotransporter. Facilitates glucose reabsorption in the kidneys

questions.text: A patient presents with high blood pressure accompanied by a decrease in heart rate. What is the most likely physiological mechanism responsible for this response?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Mechanism
  • Baroreceptors in the carotid sinus and the aortic arch detect BP changes
  • Increased BP stretches receptors, sending signals to medulla via glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves
  • Medulla inhibits vasoconstrictor center and stimulates vagal parasympathetic center

Actions
  • Vasodilation of blood vessels
  • Decreased heart rate and contraction strength
  • Reduced BP due to lower peripheral resistance and cardiac output

Importance
  • Maintains BP stability during activities like standing
  • Fastest acting
  • Tends to reset within 1-2 days for long-term regulation

questions.correct_answer: A. Sweating and vasodilation in the skin

questions.text: Identify the type of transport across the cell membrane given below.
questions.explanation:
Simple diffusion (Option A ruled out)

Facilitated diffusion (Option B)
  • Move from high to low solute concentration (downhill transport)
  • It does not require energy.
  • Not require carrier protein (channel protein may or may not be present)
  • No saturation: more concentration leads to a higher rate of transport.
  • Fick's law: Rate (J) = D.A.∆C/x
    • D: Diffusion constant.
    • A: Surface area of diffusion.
    • X: Thickness of the membrane.
    • ∆C: Concentration difference between membranes (most important determinant).
  • Movement of molecules across a membrane via carrier protein.
  • No expenditure of energy.
  • For example, glucose is transported by all types of GLUT.
  • Saturation is achieved after a certain point called the plateau.
  • The maximum transport rate occurs at the plateau or saturation point, called maximum (Tm).

Assists in glucose uptake

SGLT 1

Actively transports glucose against a concentration gradient

questions.text: Kartagener syndrome is associated with defects in which of the following structures?
questions.explanation:
Aspects

Details

Triad
  • Chronic sinusitis
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Situs inversus

Pathophysiology
  • Impaired mucociliary clearance → recurrent infections.
  • Embryonic nodal cilia dysfunction → situs inversus.

Clinical Features
  • Recurrent sinus and respiratory tract infections
  • Chronic productive cough
  • Nasal polyps
  • Otitis media with hearing loss
  • Male infertility (immotile sperm)
  • Female subfertility (impaired fallopian tube cilia)
  • Neonatal respiratory distress

questions.text: Which of the following is the principal constituent of serum osmolality?
Which of the following statements is accurate regarding creatinine clearance?
questions.explanation:
Inulin Clearance
  • Used to measure Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) as it is freely filtered but not reabsorbed or secreted.
  • Not ideal for routine use due to intravenous administration.

Creatinine Clearance
  • Estimates GFR using creatinine, which is primarily filtered by the glomeruli.
  • Slightly inaccurate due to tubular secretion, but practical for clinical settings.

PAH Clearance
  • Estimates Renal Plasma Flow (RPF).
  • PAH is cleared through both glomerular filtration and tubular secretion.
  • Correction for PAH extraction ratio improves accuracy.

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department unconscious. An arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals the following results: pH: 7.1 PCO2: 23 mmHg PO2: 98 mmHg HCO3: 16 mEq/L What do these ABG results indicate about the patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Metabolic acidosis

High anion gap

Non-anion gap

  • Methanol poisoning
  • Uremia: AKI, CKD
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Paracetamol poisoning
  • Iron and isoniazid
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Ethylene glycol poisoning
  • Salicylate poisoning
  • Hyperchloremia
  • Addison's disease
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Diarrhoea and conditions causing GI loss of HCO3- (ureterosigmoidostomy or external bowel drainage)
  • Acetazolamide
  • Spironolactone and K-sparing diuretics
  • Saline infusion (rapid infusion )

Reduced anion gap: Multiple myeloma and nephrotic syndrome

questions.text: What is the most effective stimulus for increasing aldosterone secretion ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Hyperk

Conditions that alter aldosterone secretion

A. Conditions that increase secretion
  1. Hemorrhage
  2. Hypovolemia
  3. Hyperkalemia
  4. Hyponatremia
  5. Standing
  6. Anxiety
  7. Physical trauma and surgery
  8. Secondary hyperaldosteronism: Aldosterone secretion may increase in congestive heart failure, cirrhosis of liver, and nephritic syndrome.

B. Conditions that decrease secretion
  1. Expansion of ECF volume
  2. Hypernatremia
  3. Hypokalemia

questions.text: I-125 labeled albumin is used for measurement of:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Plasma volu

Compartment

Indicator used

Total body water

D2 O, tritium oxide, Antipyrine (freely permeable to capillary and cell membranes)

ECF volume

Inulin (Best), sucrose, 22Na, 125I-iothalamate, mannitol

(freely permeable to the capillary and impermeable to the cell membrane)

ICF volume

To measure ICF volume, a substance that only distributes within cell fluid should be used. Injecting such a substance into the capillary won't allow it to bypass the ISF to enter the cell directly. Therefore, ICF volume is measured by determining TBW and ECF, and then subtracting ECF from TBW. ICF volume = (TBW - ECF)

Plasma

Evans' blue, 125I-albumin (Impermeable to capillaries)

ISF (Interstitial fluid)

ISF = (ECF – Plasma volume)

RBC

51Cr, 59Fe tagged RBC
